awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cultural Revitalization among Diasporic Native American Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Representation of Native Americans in contemporary American culture is an increasingly visible issue in the American consciousness. Social awareness of present-day Native peoples has grown considerably, but stereotypes, both negative and positive, continue to impede intercultural dialog between the federally-recognized tribes and the rest of the nation. At the same time, an ever-growing number of Native Americans are participating in acts of cultural revitalization that serve to reaffirm the culture of their respective sovereign nations and increase visibility of contemporary Native Americans to the general public. One particularly popular avenue for revitalization is through material culture, particularly for relocated tribes, where this process serves as a critical mechanism for tracing connections to ancestral lands and values. This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of scientific data collection and analysis, explores ethnic preservation among diasporic communities of the Oneida, who migrated from the northeastern United States to present-day sites in Wisconsin. The project engages with Oneida communities, including contributions to curricula for K-12 students, museum exhibits, and community center demonstrations.

This project uses a combination of ethnographic, ethnohistoric, and archaeological methods to investigate how material culture, as expressed in craftwork, has been impacted by the Wisconsin Oneida’s exposure to a wide range of intertribal and international influences both before and after removal from their native territory in the New York area. Comparing contemporary works produced by Wisconsin Oneida to those crafted in their ancestral homelands and among their sister nations of the Haudenosaunee (Iroquois) Confederacy provides insights into which cultural elements have been prioritized in their material culture and which have been altered in a manner that reflects their unique history of diaspora and cultural interaction. By addressing the popularity of different traditions and the degree to which they have been changed from recognized Iroquoian forms, the investigators can comment on the potential advantages and/or disadvantages of incorporating external cultural influences into the cultural revitalization process. The findings of this project will aid in developing a greater understanding of how cultural identity is maintained and protected by diaspora communities and Indigenous groups. Further, the development of curricular materials for K-12 educators will increase visibility of the perspectives of contemporary Native Americans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This doctoral dissertation research investigated how Native American cultural revitalization through material culture is affected by unique histories of diaspora and multicultural interaction. With support from the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant, the co-PI conducted ethnographic fieldwork and interviews with members of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin who participate in material traditions, including ceramics, maple sugaring, lacework, and beading. Additionally, the co-PI visited various institutions in the eastern United States whose collections included Oneida and/or Haudenosaunee (Iroquois) examples from these same material categories for comparative analysis.

The project selected the Wisconsin Oneida community as its research population due to its lengthy history of contact and exchange with diverse culture groups. As part of the Haudenosaunee Confederacy, the Oneida were introduced to European influences in the sixteenth century. Prior to this as well as after removal to Wisconsin in the 1820s, the Oneida likewise interacted with a broad array of Indigenous peoples. The analyses examined how consistent exposure to new materials and ideas impacted material traditions historically and how they influenced items produced through revitalization efforts.

Research findings reveal that marketability is a significant factor in design innovation, but basic form and function have experienced little change. Material categories such as ceramics and lacework particularly emphasize recreation of original pieces. Both material traditions were relatively short lived, with production ceasing completely decades prior to revitalization efforts. The focus on recovering the production methods is paramount. Significantly, both ceramics and lacework contributed to women’s social organization, as crafters producing these objects participated in occupational guilds. While the production of ceramics and thus ceramic guilds ended in the eighteenth century, lacemakers in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries reestablished a woman’s guild, challenging federal governmental efforts to dismantle female leadership in the community.

The remaining categories of maple sugaring and beadwork are technically more lucrative and have been exploited by many Indigenous communities, but the Wisconsin Oneida still prioritize their use for cultural tradition and expression. There have been discussions, however, to establish supplemental areas within the maple sugaring camp which would market sugar produced using modern industrial methods. Likewise, while beadwork will always feature heavily in craft markets, major pieces of beadwork continue to be created primarily for the community. The Wisconsin Oneida have adapted the Haudenosaunee Raised Beadwork style, still using the forms popularized in the Niagara Falls tourist market but changing the designs to reflect the values and artistry of the Oneida themselves.

Project Significance -- Intellectual Merit: Research results indicated that material culture was impacted differently by historical traditions and contemporary expression, with some categories experiencing significant innovation and others maintaining conservative designs. By focusing on four different material types, the research demonstrated the risks of evaluating cultural processes like revitalization through single object studies. Through addressing the practical and cultural factors practitioners consider when pursuing work, this study serves as an example of how to develop effective material research projects for Indigenous and diasporic communities. 

Broader Impacts: While representation is improving, funding for this dissertation research promoted participation of Indigenous people in scientific research. Community members were introduced to and actively engaged in operating scientific equipment and collecting data. In collaboration with the Oneida participants, the co-PI produced curricular materials on ceramics, lacework, and beading to complement existing curricular materials for maple sugaring. Designed for use in Wisconsin Oneida K-12 classrooms, the resources provide cultural and historical contexts with tie-ins to science and math concepts.

 


Last Modified: 08/27/2024
Modified by: Sarah E Tate
